Explanations about Options.-H(M):
Hash a known_hosts file. This replaces all hostnames and addresses with hashed
 representations within the specified file; the original content is moved to a file
 with a .old suffix. These hashes may be used normally by ssh and sshd, but they do
 not reveal identifying information should the file's contents be disclosed. This
 option will not modify existing hashed hostnames and is therefore safe to use on
 files that mix hashed and non-hashed names.
Explanations about Options.-N(C): The command looks like this: .  "ssh-keygen -p -N "" -m pem -f /path/to/key".
Explanations about Options.-f(M): Specifies the filename of the key file.
Explanations about Options.-m(C): For the full explanation of the above command, see the -m option here: https://man.openbsd.org/ssh-keygen#m.
Explanations about Options.-m(M):
Specify a key format for the -i (import) or -e (export) conversion options. The
 supported key formats are: “RFC4716” (RFC 4716/SSH2 public or private key), “PKCS8”
 (PEM PKCS8 public key) or “PEM” (PEM public key). The default conversion format is
 “RFC4716”.
Explanations about Options.-p(M):
Requests changing the passphrase of a private key file instead of creating a new
 private key. The program will prompt for the file containing the private key, for
 the old passphrase, and twice for the new passphrase.
Explanations about Options.-t(M):
Specifies the type of key to create. The possible values are “rsa1” for protocol
 version 1 and “dsa”, “ecdsa”, “ed25519”, or “rsa” for protocol version 2.

Explanations about Options.-i(M):
Use only the key(s) contained in identity_file (rather than looking for identities
 via ssh-add(1) or in the default_ID_file). If the filename does not end in .pub
 this is added. If the filename is omitted, the default_ID_file is used.
